sn47.2:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, in Ambapālī’s Wood.
sn47.2:4.2: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
sn47.2:5.1: “Mendicants, a mendicant should live mindful and aware.
sn47.2:5.2: This is my instruction to you.
sn47.2:5.3: And how is a mendicant mindful?
sn47.2:5.4: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.2:5.5: They meditate by observing an aspect of feelings …
sn47.2:5.7: principles, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.2:5.8: That’s how a mendicant is mindful.
sn47.2:6.1: And how is a mendicant aware?
sn47.2:6.2: It’s when a mendicant acts with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.
sn47.2:6.3: That’s how a mendicant acts with situational awareness.
sn47.2:6.4: A mendicant should live mindful and aware.
sn47.2:6.5: This is my instruction to you.”
